15. The empty-can (thumb-down) and full-can (thumb-up) tests are used for diagnosing supraspinatus injury.

1. The axillary nerve is the main innervation of the deltoid, allowing for abduction of the arm from 15-90 degrees.

8. Median nerve palsy can be caused by a supracondylar fracture of the humerus or a distal shaft fracture.
9. Entrapment of the median nerve causes carpal tunnel syndrome, presenting as paresthesia/numbness of the lateral hand/thenar region.
10. Carpal tunnel syndrome can be caused by hypothyroidism, acromegaly, pregnancy, or repetitive use in construction workers.
11. Treatment for carpal tunnel syndrome includes the use of a wrist pad when using a computer, wrist splint, and triamcinolone injection into the carpal tunnel.
12. Electrophysiological testing and electromyography and nerve conduction studies are the next best steps in diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome.
13. The ulnar nerve mainly innervates the medial "1 and a half" fingers and medial forearm.
14. The ulnar nerve is responsible for finger abduction and adduction (interosseous muscles).

20. The radial nerve innervates the brachioradialis, extensors, supinator, and triceps.
21. Radial nerve palsy can result from a midshaft fracture of the humerus or a fracture at the radial groove.
22. Injury to the radial nerve results in a pronated forearm and wrist drop.
23. The musculocutaneous nerve is the main innervation of the biceps.
24. Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve results in loss of sensation over the lateral forearm and decreased biceps function.

11. If untreated, a ganglion cyst may spontaneously regress.

13. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome should not be confused with Marfan syndrome, which involves fibrillin, not collagen.
14. Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy presents as arthritis and clubbing due to lung cancer.
15. The next best step in diagnosing hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is a chest x-ray.

15. Scoliosis can be associated with Marfan syndrome, Friedreich ataxia, and NF1.

1. Osteoarthritis (OA) is non-inflammatory and also known as degenerative joint disease.
2. In osteoarthritis, white blood cells (WBCs) in joint aspirates will be low (i.e., <10k/µL).
3. Patients with osteoarthritis will not have elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
4. Hip, knee, and hand findings in osteoarthritis are usually asymmetric.
5. Eburnation refers to the ivory-like appearance of bone in osteoarthritis at sites of cartilage erosion.
6. High-yield causes of osteoarthritis include obesity, being big and tall, or lifting heavy weight on the legs over many years.
7. Patients with osteoarthritis are usually, but not always, over 40-50 years old.
8. Weight loss is the number-one way to prevent and treat osteoarthritis.
9. Acetaminophen is recommended before NSAIDs for osteoarthritis treatment because it is non-inflammatory.
10. NSAIDs are not preferred for osteoarthritis because they do not offer additional benefits and can harm the kidneys.
11. Steroids (both oral and intra-articular) are not recommended for osteoarthritis treatment.
12. Injection of glycosaminoglycans and use of capsaicin cream are not recommended for osteoarthritis treatment.
13. Most NBME vignettes for osteoarthritis involve a patient over age 40-50 with a very high BMI (>40).
14. There is a case on the 2CK NBME form where the diagnosis is osteoarthritis in a young woman (32 years old) who is 6’2” and has a BMI of 30.
1. Osteoarthritis (OA) of the hands affects the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPs).
2. Heberden nodes are associated with OA in the DIPs.
3. Bouchard nodes are associated with OA in the PIPs.
4. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) does not affect the DIPs; it affects the metacarpophalangeal joints (MCPs) and PIPs.
5. RA is inflammatory, with joint aspirate generally showing >20-50k WBCs/µL.
6. A joint aspirate with <10k WBCs/µL is considered non-inflammatory, typical for OA.
7. RA is typically symmetric, whereas OA is generally asymmetric.
8. "Pannus" refers to the growth of new bone within joints in RA.
9. Most RA cases occur in women aged 20s-40s.
10. RA is often associated with other autoimmune diseases in the patient or their family members.
11. The first step in diagnosing RA in a clinical vignette is arthrocentesis.
12. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) is more specific for RA than rheumatoid factor.
13. Both anti-CCP and rheumatoid factor should be ordered for RA diagnosis.
14. NSAIDs are given first for RA symptoms, followed by steroids.
15. Disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are used to slow disease progression in RA.
16. Methotrexate is the first DMARD given for RA, followed by an anti-TNF-a agent if needed.
17. RA can cause pulmonary fibrosis/restrictive lung disease, known as rheumatoid lung.
18. Methotrexate can also cause pulmonary fibrosis.
19. RA can cause serous pericarditis (friction rub).
20. Low hemoglobin in RA indicates anemia of chronic disease.
21. Swan neck deformity in RA involves extension of the PIP and flexion of the DIP.
22. Boutonniere deformity in RA involves flexion of the PIP and extension of the DIP.
1. Rheumatoid arthritis combined with neutropenia and splenomegaly is known as Felty syndrome.

10. The diagnosis and treatment of JRA are the same as for rheumatoid arthritis.

7. Oral methotrexate is the first-line oral agent for systemic psoriasis.
